member.returns: Whether the two objects intersect.

member.name: M:FlaxEngine.CollisionsHelper.RayIntersectsRay(FlaxEngine.Ray@,FlaxEngine.Ray@,FlaxEngine.Vector3@)
member.summary: Determines whether there is an intersection between a and a .
member.param: When the method completes, contains the point of intersection, or if there was no intersection.
member.returns: Whether the two objects intersect.
member.remarks: This method performs a ray vs ray intersection test based on the following formula from Goldman. s = det([o_2 - o_1, d_2, d_1 x d_2]) / ||d_1 x d_2||^2 t = det([o_2 - o_1, d_1, d_1 x d_2]) / ||d_1 x d_2||^2 Where o_1 is the position of the first ray, o_2 is the position of the second ray, d_1 is the normalized direction of the first ray, d_2 is the normalized direction of the second ray, det denotes the determinant of a matrix, x denotes the cross product, [ ] denotes a matrix, and || || denotes the length or magnitude of a vector.

member.name: M:FlaxEngine.CollisionsHelper.RayIntersectsPlane(FlaxEngine.Ray@,FlaxEngine.Plane@,System.Single@)
member.summary: Determines whether there is an intersection between a and a .

member.returns: Whether the two objects intersect.

member.summary: Determines whether there is an intersection between a and a .

member.name: M:FlaxEngine.CollisionsHelper.RayIntersectsTriangle(FlaxEngine.Ray@,FlaxEngine.Vector3@,FlaxEngine.Vector3@,FlaxEngine.Vector3@,System.Single@)
member.summary: Determines whether there is an intersection between a and a triangle.
member.param: The first vertex of the triangle to test.
The second vertex of the triangle to test.
The third vertex of the triangle to test.
When the method completes, contains the distance of the intersection, or 0 if there was no intersection.
member.returns: Whether the two objects intersected.
member.remarks: This method tests if the ray intersects either the front or back of the triangle. If the ray is parallel to the triangle's plane, no intersection is assumed to have happened. If the intersection of the ray and the triangle is behind the origin of the ray, no intersection is assumed to have happened. In both cases of assumptions, this method returns false.

member.name: T:FlaxEngine.FloatR11G11B10
member.summary: Packed vector, layout: R:11 bytes, G:11 bytes, B:10 bytes. The 3D vector is packed into 32 bits as follows: a 5-bit biased exponent and 6-bit mantissa for x component, a 5-bit biased exponent and 6-bit mantissa for y component, a 5-bit biased exponent and a 5-bit mantissa for z. The z component is stored in the most significant bits and the x component in the least significant bits. No sign bits so all partial-precision numbers are positive. (Z10Y11X11): [32] ZZZZZzzz zzzYYYYY yyyyyyXX XXXxxxxx [0]

member.param: The floating point value that should be stored in R component (11 bits format).
The floating point value that should be stored in G component (11 bits format).
The floating point value that should be stored in B component (10 bits format).

member.name: M:FlaxEngine.Matrix3x3.Orthogonalize
member.summary: Orthogonalizes the specified Matrix3x3.

remarks.para: Orthogonalization is the process of making all rows orthogonal to each other. This means that any given row in the Matrix3x3 will be orthogonal to any other given row in the Matrix3x3.

Because this method uses the modified Gram-Schmidt process, the resulting Matrix3x3 tends to be numerically unstable. The numeric stability decreases according to the rows so that the first row is the most stable and the last row is the least stable.

This operation is performed on the rows of the Matrix3x3 rather than the columns. If you wish for this operation to be performed on the columns, first transpose the input and than transpose the output.

member.name: M:FlaxEngine.Matrix3x3.Orthonormalize
member.summary: Orthonormalizes the specified Matrix3x3.

remarks.para: Orthonormalization is the process of making all rows and columns orthogonal to each other and making all rows and columns of unit length. This means that any given row will be orthogonal to any other given row and any given column will be orthogonal to any other given column. Any given row will not be orthogonal to any given column. Every row and every column will be of unit length.

Because this method uses the modified Gram-Schmidt process, the resulting Matrix3x3 tends to be numerically unstable. The numeric stability decreases according to the rows so that the first row is the most stable and the last row is the least stable.

This operation is performed on the rows of the Matrix3x3 rather than the columns. If you wish for this operation to be performed on the columns, first transpose the input and than transpose the output.

member.summary: Decomposes a Matrix3x3 into an orthonormalized Matrix3x3 q and a right triangular Matrix3x3 r.
member.param: When the method completes, contains the orthonormalized Matrix3x3 of the decomposition.
When the method completes, contains the right triangular Matrix3x3 of the decomposition.

member.param: When the method completes, contains the lower triangular Matrix3x3 of the decomposition.
When the method completes, contains the orthonormalized Matrix3x3 of the decomposition.

member.summary: Decomposes a uniform scale matrix into a scale, rotation, and translation. A uniform scale matrix has the same scale in every axis.
member.param: When the method completes, contains the scaling component of the decomposed matrix.
When the method completes, contains the rotation component of the decomposed matrix.
member.remarks: This method is designed to decompose only an SRT transformation matrix that has the same scale in every axis.

member.name: M:FlaxEngine.Matrix3x3.Orthogonalize(FlaxEngine.Matrix3x3@,FlaxEngine.Matrix3x3@)
member.summary: Orthogonalizes the specified Matrix3x3.
member.param: When the method completes, contains the orthogonalized Matrix3x3.

remarks.para: Orthogonalization is the process of making all rows orthogonal to each other. This means that any given row in the Matrix3x3 will be orthogonal to any other given row in the Matrix3x3.

Because this method uses the modified Gram-Schmidt process, the resulting Matrix3x3 tends to be numerically unstable. The numeric stability decreases according to the rows so that the first row is the most stable and the last row is the least stable.

This operation is performed on the rows of the Matrix3x3 rather than the columns. If you wish for this operation to be performed on the columns, first transpose the input and than transpose the output.

member.name: M:FlaxEngine.Matrix3x3.Orthogonalize(FlaxEngine.Matrix3x3)
member.summary: Orthogonalizes the specified Matrix3x3.
member.returns: The orthogonalized Matrix3x3.

remarks.para: Orthogonalization is the process of making all rows orthogonal to each other. This means that any given row in the Matrix3x3 will be orthogonal to any other given row in the Matrix3x3.

Because this method uses the modified Gram-Schmidt process, the resulting Matrix3x3 tends to be numerically unstable. The numeric stability decreases according to the rows so that the first row is the most stable and the last row is the least stable.

This operation is performed on the rows of the Matrix3x3 rather than the columns. If you wish for this operation to be performed on the columns, first transpose the input and than transpose the output.

member.name: M:FlaxEngine.Matrix3x3.Orthonormalize(FlaxEngine.Matrix3x3@,FlaxEngine.Matrix3x3@)
member.summary: Orthonormalizes the specified Matrix3x3.
member.param: When the method completes, contains the orthonormalized Matrix3x3.

remarks.para: Orthonormalization is the process of making all rows and columns orthogonal to each other and making all rows and columns of unit length. This means that any given row will be orthogonal to any other given row and any given column will be orthogonal to any other given column. Any given row will not be orthogonal to any given column. Every row and every column will be of unit length.

Because this method uses the modified Gram-Schmidt process, the resulting Matrix3x3 tends to be numerically unstable. The numeric stability decreases according to the rows so that the first row is the most stable and the last row is the least stable.

This operation is performed on the rows of the Matrix3x3 rather than the columns. If you wish for this operation to be performed on the columns, first transpose the input and than transpose the output.

member.name: M:FlaxEngine.Matrix3x3.Orthonormalize(FlaxEngine.Matrix3x3)
member.summary: Orthonormalizes the specified Matrix3x3.
member.returns: The orthonormalized Matrix3x3.

remarks.para: Orthonormalization is the process of making all rows and columns orthogonal to each other and making all rows and columns of unit length. This means that any given row will be orthogonal to any other given row and any given column will be orthogonal to any other given column. Any given row will not be orthogonal to any given column. Every row and every column will be of unit length.

Because this method uses the modified Gram-Schmidt process, the resulting Matrix3x3 tends to be numerically unstable. The numeric stability decreases according to the rows so that the first row is the most stable and the last row is the least stable.

This operation is performed on the rows of the Matrix3x3 rather than the columns. If you wish for this operation to be performed on the columns, first transpose the input and than transpose the output.

member.summary: Brings the Matrix3x3 into upper triangular form using elementary row operations.
member.param: The Matrix3x3 to put into upper triangular form.
When the method completes, contains the upper triangular Matrix3x3.
member.remarks: If the Matrix3x3 is not invertible (i.e. its determinant is zero) than the result of this method may produce Single.Nan and Single.Inf values. When the Matrix3x3 represents a system of linear equations, than this often means that either no solution exists or an infinite number of solutions exist.

member.name: M:FlaxEngine.OrientedBoundingBox.Merge(FlaxEngine.OrientedBoundingBox@,FlaxEngine.OrientedBoundingBox@,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Merge an OrientedBoundingBox B into another OrientedBoundingBox A, by expanding A to contain B and keeping A orientation.
member.param: If true, the method will use a fast algorithm which is inapplicable if a scale is applied to the transformation matrix of the OrientedBoundingBox.
member.remarks: Unlike merging axis aligned boxes, The operation is not interchangeable, because it keeps A orientation and merge B into it.

member.name: M:FlaxEngine.Assertions.Assert.AreApproximatelyEqual(System.Single,System.Single)
member.summary: Asserts that the values are approximately equal. An absolute error check is used for approximate equality check (|a-b| < tolerance). Default tolerance is 0.00001f. Note: Every time you call the method with tolerance specified, a new instance of Assertions.Comparers.FloatComparer is created. For performance reasons you might want to instance your own comparer and pass it to the AreEqual method. If the tolerance is not specifies, a default comparer is used and the issue does not occur.

member.name: T:FlaxEngine.PostProcessEffect
member.summary: Custom postFx which can modify final image by processing it with material based filters. The base class for all post process effects used by the graphics pipeline. Allows to extend frame rendering logic and apply custom effects such as outline, night vision, contrast etc.
member.remarks: Override this class and implement custom post fx logic. Use MainRenderTask.Instance.CustomPostFx.Add(myPostFx) to attach your script to rendering. Or add script to camera.

member.name: P:FlaxEngine.PostProcessEffect.CanRender
member.summary: Gets a value indicating whether this effect can be rendered.

member.name: P:FlaxEngine.PostProcessEffect.UseSingleTarget
member.summary: Gets a value indicating whether use a single render target as both input and output. Use this if your effect doesn't need to copy the input buffer to the output but can render directly to the single texture. Can be used to optimize game performance.

member.name: P:FlaxEngine.PostProcessEffect.Location
member.summary: Gets the effect rendering location within rendering pipeline.

member.name: P:FlaxEngine.PostProcessEffect.Order
member.summary: Gets the effect rendering order. Registered post effects are sorted before rendering (from the lowest order to the highest order).

member.name: M:FlaxEngine.PostProcessEffect.Render(FlaxEngine.GPUContext,FlaxEngine.RenderContext@,FlaxEngine.GPUTexture,FlaxEngine.GPUTexture)
member.summary: Performs custom postFx rendering.

member.name: M:FlaxEngine.Object.Destroy(FlaxEngine.Object,System.Single)
member.summary: Destroys the specified object and clears the reference variable. The object obj will be destroyed now or after the time specified in seconds from now. If obj is a Script it will be removed from the Actor and deleted. If obj is an Actor it will be removed from the Scene and deleted as well as all its Scripts and all children of the Actor. Actual object destruction is always delayed until after the current Update loop, but will always be done before rendering.
member.param: The time left to destroy object (in seconds).

member.name: M:FlaxEngine.Object.Destroy``1(``0@,System.Single)
member.summary: Destroys the specified object and clears the reference variable. The object obj will be destroyed now or after the time specified in seconds from now. If obj is a Script it will be removed from the Actor and deleted. If obj is an Actor it will be removed from the Scene and deleted as well as all its Scripts and all children of the Actor. Actual object destruction is always delayed until after the current Update loop, but will always be done before rendering.
member.param: The time left to destroy object (in seconds).

member.name: M:FlaxEngine.Object.op_Implicit(FlaxEngine.Object)~System.Boolean
member.summary: Checks if the object exists (reference is not null and the unmanaged object pointer is valid).
member.returns: True if object is valid, otherwise false.

member.summary: Gets the pointer to the native object. Handles null object reference (returns zero).
member.returns: The native object pointer.

member.name: M:FlaxEngine.Object.GetUnmanagedInterface(System.Object,System.Type)
member.summary: Gets the pointer to the native interface implementation. Handles null object reference or invalid cast (returns zero).
member.returns: The native interface pointer.

member.name: P:FlaxEngine.GUI.Control.Scale
member.summary: Gets or sets the scale. Scales control according to its Pivot which by default is (0.5,0.5) (middle of the control). If you set pivot to (0,0) it will scale the control based on it's upper-left corner.

member.name: P:FlaxEngine.GUI.Control.Pivot
member.summary: Gets or sets the normalized pivot location (used to transform control around it). Point (0,0) is upper left corner, (0.5,0.5) is center, (1,1) is bottom right corner.

member.name: P:FlaxEngine.GUI.Control.Shear
member.summary: Gets or sets the shear transform angles (x, y). Defined in degrees. Shearing happens relative to the control pivot point.

member.summary: Gets or sets the rotation angle (in degrees). Control is rotated around it's pivot point (middle of the control by default).

member.name: T:FlaxEngine.CanvasRenderMode
member.summary: The canvas rendering modes.

member.name: F:FlaxEngine.CanvasRenderMode.ScreenSpace
member.summary: The screen space rendering mode that places UI elements on the screen rendered on top of the scene. If the screen is resized or changes resolution, the Canvas will automatically change size to match this.

member.name: F:FlaxEngine.CanvasRenderMode.CameraSpace
member.summary: The camera space rendering mode that places Canvas in a given distance in front of a specified Camera. The UI elements are rendered by this camera, which means that the Camera settings affect the appearance of the UI. If the Camera is set to Perspective, the UI elements will be rendered with perspective, and the amount of perspective distortion can be controlled by the Camera Field of View. If the screen is resized, changes resolution, or the camera frustum changes, the Canvas will automatically change size to match as well.

member.name: F:FlaxEngine.CanvasRenderMode.WorldSpace
member.summary: The world space rendering mode that places Canvas as any other object in the scene. The size of the Canvas can be set manually using its Transform, and UI elements will render in front of or behind other objects in the scene based on 3D placement. This is useful for UIs that are meant to be a part of the world. This is also known as a 'diegetic interface'.

member.name: F:FlaxEngine.CanvasRenderMode.WorldSpaceFaceCamera
member.summary: The world space rendering mode that places Canvas as any other object in the scene and orients it to face the camera. The size of the Canvas can be set manually using its Transform, and UI elements will render in front of or behind other objects in the scene based on 3D placement. This is useful for UIs that are meant to be a part of the world. This is also known as a 'diegetic interface'.

member.summary: If checked, enables automatic navmesh actors spawning on a scenes that are using it during navigation building.

member.name: F:FlaxEditor.Content.Settings.NavigationSettings.AutoRemoveMissingNavMeshes
member.summary: If checked, enables automatic navmesh actors removing from a scenes that are not using it during navigation building.

member.name: F:FlaxEditor.Content.Settings.NavigationSettings.CellHeight
member.summary: The height of a grid cell in the navigation mesh building steps using heightfields. A lower number means higher precision on the vertical axis but longer build times.

member.name: F:FlaxEditor.Content.Settings.NavigationSettings.CellSize
member.summary: The width/height of a grid cell in the navigation mesh building steps using heightfields. A lower number means higher precision on the horizontal axes but longer build times.

member.name: F:FlaxEditor.Content.Settings.NavigationSettings.TileSize
member.summary: Tile size used for Navigation mesh tiles, the final size of a tile is CellSize*TileSize.

member.name: F:FlaxEditor.Content.Settings.NavigationSettings.MinRegionArea
member.summary: The minimum number of cells allowed to form isolated island areas.

member.name: F:FlaxEditor.Content.Settings.NavigationSettings.MergeRegionArea
member.summary: Any regions with a span count smaller than this value will, if possible, be merged with larger regions.

member.name: F:FlaxEditor.Content.Settings.NavigationSettings.MaxEdgeLen
member.summary: The maximum allowed length for contour edges along the border of the mesh.

member.name: F:FlaxEditor.Content.Settings.NavigationSettings.MaxEdgeError
member.summary: The maximum distance a simplified contour's border edges should deviate from the original raw contour.

member.name: F:FlaxEditor.Content.Settings.NavigationSettings.DetailSamplingDist

member.summary: The default gravity force value (in cm^2/s).

member.name: F:FlaxEditor.Content.Settings.PhysicsSettings.QueriesHitTriggers
member.summary: If enabled, any Raycast or other scene query that intersects with a Collider marked as a Trigger will returns with a hit. Individual raycasts can override this behavior.

member.name: F:FlaxEditor.Content.Settings.PhysicsSettings.TriangleMeshTriangleMinAreaThreshold
member.summary: Triangles from triangle meshes (CSG) with an area less than or equal to this value will be removed from physics collision data. Set to less than or equal 0 to disable.

member.name: F:FlaxEditor.Content.Settings.PhysicsSettings.BounceThresholdVelocity
member.summary: Minimum relative velocity required for an object to bounce. A typical value for simulation stability is about 0.2 * gravity

member.name: F:FlaxEditor.Content.Settings.PhysicsSettings.FrictionCombineMode
member.summary: Default friction combine mode, controls how friction is computed for multiple materials.

member.name: F:FlaxEditor.Content.Settings.PhysicsSettings.RestitutionCombineMode
member.summary: Default restitution combine mode, controls how restitution is computed for multiple materials.

member.name: F:FlaxEditor.Content.Settings.PhysicsSettings.DisableCCD
member.summary: If true CCD will be ignored. This is an optimization when CCD is never used which removes the need for physx to check it internally.

member.name: F:FlaxEditor.Content.Settings.PhysicsSettings.EnableAdaptiveForce
member.summary: Enables adaptive forces to accelerate convergence of the solver. Can improve physics simulation performance but lead to artifacts.

member.name: F:FlaxEditor.Content.Settings.PhysicsSettings.MaxDeltaTime
member.summary: The maximum allowed delta time (in seconds) for the physics simulation step.

member.name: F:FlaxEditor.Content.Settings.PhysicsSettings.EnableSubstepping
member.summary: Whether to substep the physics simulation.

member.name: F:FlaxEditor.Content.Settings.PhysicsSettings.SubstepDeltaTime
member.summary: Delta time (in seconds) for an individual simulation substep.

member.name: F:FlaxEditor.Content.Settings.PhysicsSettings.MaxSubsteps
member.summary: The maximum number of substeps for physics simulation.

member.name: F:FlaxEditor.Content.Settings.PhysicsSettings.SupportCookingAtRuntime
member.summary: Enables support for cooking physical collision shapes geometry at runtime. Use it to enable generating runtime terrain collision or convex mesh colliders.

member.name: F:FlaxEditor.Content.Settings.PhysicsSettings.LayerMasks
member.summary: The collision layers masks. Used to define layer-based collision detection.
